5. 
was not communicated to any member of the Expedition, 
but its desirability was obvious to the most ordinary 
intelligence. There were insuperable difficulties 
to such a course however, apart from the consideration 
of space below. The Vane head had necessarily to be 
placed in a position free from the interference of the 
rigging of the Ship; such a position could only be found 
on the Mizzen Mast from whence to the living space the 
conducting pipe must necessarily have been very long and 
angular, to the complete detriment of accurate results. 
Moreover, had this small pipe been lashed to the stove 
pipe it would inevitably have been choked with ice 
whenever the temperature fell (This evil was constantly 
felt in the Acetylene installation, although the generator 
was in the lobby and not in the open. With great and 
varying differences of temperature at the ends of a pipe 
internal condensation is unavoidable). 
The installation of the 'Dines' Anemograph 
was arranged with a knowledge of the principles involved 
and the best was made of difficult circumstances. 
The instrument failed from a cause which 
might have been foreseen but which could not have been 
prevented, namely the collection of ice crystals in and 
about the vane head; it is therefore clearly unfitted 
for polar work. 
<u>The<\u>
